articles.headline: Afghan Army Attracts Few Where Fear Reigns
articles.snippet: The small number of southern Pashtuns in the Afghan Army reflects an abiding fear of the Taliban, or sympathy for them, and doubts about the government.
articles.abstract: The small number of southern Pashtuns in the Afghan Army reflects an abiding fear of the Taliban, or sympathy for them, and doubts about the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Every morning, jobless young men gather by the hundreds at the busy central square here in this southern city, desperate for whatever work they can find. In other places, this would be an army recruiter’s dream. Not so in Kandahar.

articles.headline: Enlisted in the World of Airborne Spying
articles.snippet: The military has been snapping up used luxury aircraft to fulfill its need for more surveillance planes.
articles.abstract: The military has been snapping up used luxury aircraft to fulfill its need for more surveillance planes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For four years, a doctor commuted between his clinics in Texas in a $5 million turboprop with jazzy metallic stripes and ruby stones embedded on the drink cabinet inside. The plane featured exotic wood veneers and polished chrome, and his daughter’s initials were in the tail number.

articles.headline: Yahoo Board Fires Chief Executive
articles.snippet: The firing of Carol A. Bartz ended a rocky two-year tenure in which she tried to revitalize the company.
articles.abstract: The firing of Carol A. Bartz ended a rocky two-year tenure in which she tried to revitalize the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo’s chief executive, was fired Tuesday, ending a rocky two-year tenure in which she tried to revitalize the online media company.
articles.byline: By Verne G. Kopytoff and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Old Tax Relief Seen as Anchor in Obama Plan
articles.snippet: Extending the payroll tax reduction is not the president’s first policy choice, but it may have the best chance of getting G.O.P. support.
articles.abstract: Extending the payroll tax reduction is not the president’s first policy choice, but it may have the best chance of getting G.O.P. support.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The centerpiece of the job creation package that President Obama plans to announce on Thursday — payroll tax relief for workers and perhaps their employers — is neither his first policy choice nor that of many economists. But it is the one that they figure has the best chance of getting Republicans’ support.

articles.headline: Plan Would Keep Small Force in Iraq Past Deadline
articles.snippet: A recommendation from Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta to keep troops in Iraq beyond 2011 would break a longstanding pledge by President Obama.
articles.abstract: A recommendation from Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta to keep troops in Iraq beyond 2011 would break a longstanding pledge by President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is supporting a plan that would keep 3,000 to 4,000 American troops in Iraq after a deadline for their withdrawal at year’s end, but only to continue training security forces there, a senior military official said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: In Euro Zone, Banking Fear Feeds on Itself
articles.snippet: Questions continue to mount about the ability of Europe’s banks to ride out the debt crisis, as some are having a harder time securing loans needed for daily operations.
articles.abstract: Questions continue to mount about the ability of Europe’s banks to ride out the debt crisis, as some are having a harder time securing loans needed for daily operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember the collapse of Lehman Brothers? Europeans certainly do.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Nelson D. Schwartz
